text:
What did women in Canada find out?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. J. B. Hickey
Address: Box 121, Bethune, Sask.
Birthplace: Allonby, Northumberland, England

1. INDUSTRIAL HISTORY

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1912
Where did you set up housekeeping? Bethune, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Henry, England
For how many people did you prepare meals? Sixteen or fewer
How far was it to your nearest store? About two miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? At least once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, tea, rolled oats, prunes, macaroni, lard, sugar syrup, m. beans, rice, small items like spices etc., salt, pepper & mustard

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household
In what quantities did you buy it? About 30 lbs. for a year
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 25¢
How much did you use graham flour? A small quantity occasionally
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? 37½ miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 96¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole wheat? Yes
Farina? Yes
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? With a hand mill, bought in 50 lb bags
1912. Hickey, Mrs. J.B.
Box 21, Bethune, Canada

Interview Questions:

1. What year did you start living in Bethune?

   - Where did you move from before that?
   - Answer: [Blank]

3. **BEVERAGES**

In what quantity did you buy milk? (in lbs.)

That was the price for a ten pound box of whole milk?

What brand of milk did you usually buy?

What size of tin or cup did you usually use?

At what prices?

4. **DAIRY PRODUCTS**

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Did you make butter?

Did you make cheese?

What kind of cheese?

5. **MEAT AND FISH**

What was your meat supply in the early days?

Did you eat fish?

How often did you eat fish?

Did you purchase meat?

Was there a meat market in your neighborhood?

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet?

Was the fish fresh, canned, or preserved?

Kind of fish?
3. **BEANS AND STUFFS**
   - In what quantity did you buy "Allie beans"? (in lbs.)
     - This was the price for a ten pound sack of whole beans?
     - Brand of beans came from? Did you use it?
     - Size of tin or syrup did you usually buy at that price?

4. **DAIRY PRODUCTS**
   - How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?
     - Butter made locally
     - That was two quarts of butter?
     - Did you make your own?
     - Did you make butter?
     - What kind of cheese?

5. **MEAT AND FISH**
   - What was your meat supply in the early days?
     - How did you get fresh meat?
     - How often did you eat fresh meat?
     - How did you preserve meat?
     - Was there a "meat shop" in your neighborhood?
     - If so what year was it organized?
     - Did you use meat?
     - For how long?
     - What was the main meat in the family diet?
     - Was the fish fresh, canned, or smoked?
     - Kind of fish
6. Buyings:
   - What kind of tea did you buy? (black, green)
   - At what price?
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (ground or cream)
   - Price?
   - Other beverages used?

7. Vegetables and Fruits:
   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you bought them?
   - Could you get potatoes at the store?
   - If not, where from?
   - What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter?
   - Potatoes:
     - Turnips:
     - Carrots:
     - Cabbages:
   - In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?
   - How did you buy prunes? (in bulk or by the box)?
   - What weights?
   - How did the grocer handle prunes?
   - What other dried fruits did you use in the winter?
   - Apples, pears, apricots, peaches, lemons, raisins, currants or oranges?

8. Preserving:
   - In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying?
   - Pass?
   - Beans?
   - Other foods?
   - That year did you first preserve fruit by canning?
   - What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?
   - That year did you first preserve meat by canning?
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?
   - To what extent?
   - Did you make your own vinegar?
6. **BEVERAGES**
   - What kind of tea did you buy? [Blank]
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) [Blank]
   - Retailer [Blank]

7. **VEGETABLES AND FRUITS**
   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel? [Blank]
   - Could you get potatoes at the store? [Blank]
   - If not, where from? [Blank]
   - What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter? [Blank]
   - Potatoes [Blank]
   - Turnips [Blank]

   - How did you buy potatoes? (in bulk or by the box)? [Blank]

   - What other dried fruits did you use in the summer days? (apricots, peaches, apricots, pears, raisins, currants, or others)? [Blank]

8. **PRESERVES**
   - In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? [Blank]
   - Other [Blank]
   - Beans? [Blank]
   - Satisfactory? [Blank]
   - That year did you first preserve fruits by canning? [Blank]
   - That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? [Blank]
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? [Blank]
   - To that extent? [Blank]
   - Did you make your own preserves? [Blank]

10. Did you make your own yeast? Yes

Did you make your own salt rising? Yes

Did you make your own baking soda? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? Yes

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, dugout)

If so, was this water from your house?

How was it brought to the house? (Well, barrel, tank)

Has any change been made in the water supply since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.
13. SMS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If so, how?

If you make your own, did you use lye? If so, how much?

Did you use any other substances in the wash water? If so, what?

14. FUEL

Coal

That fuel did you use in the fall at 50°? If so, how much?

There did you not your fuel? If so, why?

Ration any chances in the use of fuel which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, stating dates where possible.

Took you use wood or coal? If so, why?

Charged this year to a boiler furnace using a small coal (either coal)

15. IMPELERS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) If so, when?

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) If so, when?

By whom was your first cook stove made? (Name) Price?

What year was it purchased? (Give date)

That type of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, earthenware)

For preparing food? (Glass, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first use metal pans? (Give date)

Aluminum?
13. USING

Did you buy laundry goods in any store? Yes or No.

If so, what store? Yes or No.

What kind of laundry soap did you use? Yes or No.

There was no such thing as "laundry soap" then.

14. FUEL

That fuel did you use in the earliest days? Yes or No.

There was no such thing as "fuel" then.

Mention any changes in the use of fuel which have taken place since you lived there.

15. HEATING AND COOLING METHODS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? Yes or No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? Yes or No.

By whom was your first book stove made? Yes or No.

Next year was it purchased by whom? Yes or No.

What type of material did you use? Yes or No.

For preserving food (canning, pickling, etc.) what vessels, tools?

When did you first use metal vessels? Yes or No.

Aluminum?
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate monthly cost, winter or summer.

1912. Breakfast: oatmeal, bacon & eggs.

My husband & his children: April 30th, 1912.

Myself: April 28th, 1912.

Dinner: canned meat, rice, pickled fruit.

Soup: macaroni & cheese.

What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

1913. My husband & I had a baby boy (Hugh) of 1 year.

Christmas dinner: ham, potatoes, cranberry sauce, pie.

Locally produced foods? Give details.

19. Have you ever refused to accept starvation level living on any occasion?

Yes.

We killed beef & pork in the fall; fall was very short. We pickled & dried & kept some for spring use. We also had a little in storage. We also canned chicken & fruit if available.
15. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

17. Breakfast: rolled oats, bacon & eggs

My husband, his birthday, April 28th, 1918.

Myself, 28th April, 1918.

That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Canada? 1918.

My husband, 31st, his birthday, August 14th.

Question: If a baby boy, what would you name him?

Grape, cranberry sauce, prune, molasses pudding & mincemeat.

19. Have you ever resorted to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Quo:

We killed beef & pork in the fall; fell some hams we pickled & dried, kept some fresh in the fall; also had a lot of flour, sugar, molasses, applesauce, etc.

We also canned chicken & fruit if available.
We often had our own bacon beef.

In 1916 we started to order fruit from

B. C. a school district would club together

and regularly a fruit would be shipped an

alfred, the fruit was perfect & quite

different to the fruit shipped in its local

area. We still make our own butter, cannot

afford fruit if possible & make bread.

We used to buy a large order from one of

the big wholesale houses, its quality was

better & fresher, buying in quantities

the prices were better, I cannot think

of those days, but it was a

terrible difference I know from the funeral

day if they're anything else you will

not know, it will arrive. Isn't that

how we anymore human here in our

home. So nice apr. 27th
We started our own creamery in 1916. We started to sell cream & eggs to the creamery. We always took our own bread, made our own cakes, brownies, etc., which were quite a big order during harvest time. Today we can buy necessary bread, cakes, etc., from the store.

In 1916 we started to order fruit from B.C. a school district around us together. We send together a friend to collect the apples and pears. The fruit was perfect & quite different to the fruit shipped in to the local stores. We also make our own butter, canned apples & fruit if possible & make bread.

Plants and other details free. Your early cooperation of buying generous orders will be appreciated. We are further pleased to have in our community a wholesale grocer of sterling quality, methods of merchandising, the best of prices and service. It is our privilege to serve you.

We used to buy a large order from one of the big wholesale houses, its quality was better & fresher & buying in quantities. We prefer our own butters, canned fruits & other things, but it wasn't a terrible difference if bought from the farmer's market in anything else. You said you'd like to know, if we'll answer. I don't think so, any more. Please write soon.
Oxford

No. 613 S
